result.execSummary:
On one or more charges, the deferred prosecution or sentencing agreement(s) on this case were fulfilled, and the charge(s) were dismissed.

The defendant Jerry D. Jones Jr. was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Jerry D. Jones Jr.
parties.address: 22 Main St, Apt 6, Black River Falls, WI 54615

parties.name: Jackson County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes: The State has 30 days to submit any restitution information.  AMENDED 3/31/16.  Pursuant to restitution order signed 3/31/16.  No restitution ordered.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, with the victims.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

The court does not have any objection to the defendant leaving the jurisdiction, as long as he coordinates the same with his agent, to fight fires in other States or in Canada.

ADDRESS INFO for Jerry D. Jones Jr.

Restitution order.

DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Sherman.  Victim notification complied with, per DA.    Defendant plead guilty to the charges.  Count 1 to be subject to  DPA. Count 2, 1 year probation.  AODA, no alc.  maintain employment.  Court recited the charges and possible penalties of the the charges he plead to.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Felony warnings given. Defendant understood.  Court confirmed that the defendant understood the DPA and will be able to comply with the conditions.  He said he understands the agreement and can comply.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.  Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Finding withheld on Count 1.   DPA approved.   Found guilty of count 2.    Joint recommendation for 1 year probation on count 2.  AODA, maintain employment.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Defendant did not exercise his right to allocution.  Court ordered sentence withheld, 1 year probation on count 2.    Defendant to have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, with the victims.  Court does not have an objection for leaving the jurisdiction as long as he cooredinates the same with his agent, to fight fires in other states or Canada.  Maintain employment.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  State has 30 days to submit restitution information.  CC, DNA submission and surcharge.
Plea/sentencing hearing at 12-14-2015 01:30 pm

Defendant appeared with counsel Jon Sherman.  Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Attorney Sherman states they have an agreement and case can be set for plea/sentencing.  Court schedules for 12/14/15 at 1:30.  Jury trial for 12-17-15 can be removed from calendar.

DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant did not appear.  Attorney Sherman appeared.  No agreement yet.  State requests that it be set for JT.  Attorney Sherman agrees.  2 day trial.
Pre-trial conference at 09-16-2015 10:00 am
Status conference at 10-05-2015 03:00 pm
Waive reading of information.  Mute.   PTC 9/16 & STC 10/5/15.

DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Sherman.  State called Officer T.C., sworn.  State questioned witness.   Witness identified the defendant.  Record reflects identification.  Exhibit 1 marked.  Medical record of D.L.  State moves for admission of exhibit 1.  No objection.  Admitted.  Venue established.  Attorney Sherman questioned witness.  State moves for bind over.  Defense has no witnesses.  Court finds probable cause.
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on Officer T.C. to appear at preliminary hearing.
Preliminary hearing at 08-26-2015 08:30 am
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on  Officer T.C. to appear at 7/23/15 preliminary hearing.
Preliminary hearing at 07-23-2015 01:30 pm
DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Sherman.  Attorney Sherman needs more discovery.  Set for preliminary hearing.  45 minutes.
Not signed by Judge - she wrote a note at the bottom.  "The court can only approve for misdemeanors per 971.04(2).  These are felony charges." (Sent a copy to Sherman)

Until further order of the court, you shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, except through your attorney, with any of the following individuals and/or businesses:D. L. and G. W..  Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request. Report for booking.

Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the wavier of time limits.  Defendant stated that he understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived the time limits for holding the preliminary hearing.
